newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan coffee firms resist price hike despite rally.
newsitem.headline: Japan coffee firms resist price hike despite rally.

text.p: Japanese roasters, while increasingly worried about rallying global coffee prices, are resisting pressure to raise wholesale prices yet again for fear of losing market share, industry officials said on Friday.
"The recent rallies in coffee prices are crazy. We're worried about how far prices will rise," said Hisashi Nishida, an Ajinomoto General Foods Inc (AGF) spokesman.
"We raised wholesale coffee prices this month and are still trying to persuade customers to accept the higher prices," he said. "We have no specific plans to raise prices again at this stage."

AGF, one of Japan's leading coffee roasters, raised its wholesale coffee price by nearly 10 percent from May 1, reflecting surging global coffee prices and the yen's decline against the dollar since early this year.
AGF is a joint venture between Japan's Ajinomoto Co Inc and Philip Morris Cos Inc's Kraft Foods International Inc.
New York arabica coffee futures soared to a 20-year peak on Thursday in the third straight day of a rally that saw prices shatter the $3.00 a pound barrier.
Although prices have been soaring since early this year, local coffee prices have hardly budged.
Doutor Coffee Co, Japan's largest coffee shop chain with about 460 outlets nationwide, is currently selling Brazilian coffee beans at 700 yen per 200 grams.

"Japanese consumers are becoming increasingly sensitive to prices differentials (between roasters). Market share is easily lost by raising prices," said Takeshi Kubota, Doutor's Kamiyacho branch manager.
Another major roaster, UCC Ueshima Coffee Co Ltd, which raised wholesale prices by about 20 percent in May, said it has no immediate plan to increase prices again.
